description: From Middle English rebel, rebell, from Old French rebelle, from Latin rebellis (“waging war again; insurgent”), from rebellō (“I wage war again, fight back”), from re- (“again, back”) + bellō (“I wage war”).

entries.meaning: A person who resists an established authority, often violently.
examples: A group of rebels defied the general's orders and split off from the main army.
My little sister is such a rebel - coming home late, piercing her ears, and refusing to do any of her chores.

entries.meaning: (US, historical) Synonym of Confederate: a citizen of the Confederate States of America, especially a Confederate soldier.

description: From Middle English rebellen, from Old French rebeller, from Latin rebellō (“I wage war again, fight back”), from re- (“again, back”) + bellō (“I wage war”). Doublet of revel.

verbs.description: rebel (third-person singular simple present rebels, present participle rebelling, simple past and past participle rebelled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To resist or become defiant toward an authority.
